review.title: Iterated Belief Change Due to Actions and Observations
review.abstract: In action domains where agents may have erroneous beliefs, reasoning about the effects of actions involves reasoning about belief change. In this paper, we use a transition system approach to reason about the evolution of an agents beliefs as actions are executed. Some actions cause an agent to perform belief revision while others cause an agent to perform belief update, but the interaction between revision and update can be non-elementary. We present a set of rationality properties describing the interaction between revision and update, and we introduce a new class of belief change operators for reasoning about alternating sequences of revisions and updates. Our belief change operators can be characterized in terms of a natural shifting operation on total pre-orderings over interpretations. We compare our approach with related work on iterated belief change due to action, and we conclude with some directions for future research.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: We are interested in modelling the change of faith caused by performing an alternate sequence of actions and observations. Broadly speaking, agents perform faith actualizations by actions, and agents perform faith actualizations by observations. However, to date there has been little explicit consideration of the repeated change of faith that occurs when an observation follows a sequence of actions. In this paper, we deal with faith actualizations in the context of sequences of the following form. (InitialBeliefs) · · (Observation) · (Observation) · (Observation) (1) We assume that the effects of actions are fully specified and infallible. We illustrate that the faith actualizations caused by this type of alternating sequence cannot simply be determined by a simple iteration of updates and revisions. The main problem is that there are plausible examples in which an observation should cause an agent to revise the original state of faith rather than the present state.
